comments.body: Quote from: sportbettor on May 08, 2022, 07:53:16 PM...but cryptocurrency sportsbooks unfortunately do not have the UK license.Actually, that's inaccurate.The UKGC license doesn't easily allow holders to accept crypto deposits. In that list I count at least 2 of the crypto bookies you mentioned who actually do have the UKGC license, so I know for sure you're mistaken So while they're known as crypto bookies, it is simply that their UK versions of casinos/books don't accept crypto deposits.

comments.author: Daltonik
comments.body: Quote from: buwaytress on August 16, 2022, 03:57:15 PMQuote from: sportbettor on May 08, 2022, 07:53:16 PM...but cryptocurrency sportsbooks unfortunately do not have the UK license.Actually, that's inaccurate.The UKGC license doesn't allow holders to accept crypto deposits. In that list I count at least 2 of the crypto bookies you mentioned who actually do have the UKGC license, so I know for sure you're mistaken So while they're known as crypto bookies, it is simply that their UK versions of casinos/books don't accept crypto deposits.Indeed, since October 2016, there have been changes in the UKGC licensing in LCCP that allow online casinos to use bitcoin as a monetary equivalent. What I managed to find about this is section 7 on page 31 https://assets.ctfassets.net/j16ev64qyf6l/UOi6gMu0H8cOL32OcuKMi/28650a334736ab552fc16a625303168f/LCCP-crime-review-responses-May-2016.pdf The news itself https://www.newsbtc.com/news/ukgc-declares-bitcoin-as-cash-equivalent/

comments.author: buwaytress
comments.body: Quote from: Daltonik on August 16, 2022, 05:26:58 PMQuote from: buwaytress on August 16, 2022, 03:57:15 PMQuote from: sportbettor on May 08, 2022, 07:53:16 PM...but cryptocurrency sportsbooks unfortunately do not have the UK license.So while they're known as crypto bookies, it is simply that their UK versions of casinos/books don't accept crypto deposits.Indeed, since October 2016, there have been changes in the UKGC licensing in LCCP that allow online casinos to use bitcoin as a monetary equivalent. What I managed to find about this is section 7 on page 31 https://assets.ctfassets.net/j16ev64qyf6l/UOi6gMu0H8cOL32OcuKMi/28650a334736ab552fc16a625303168f/LCCP-crime-review-responses-May-2016.pdf The news itself https://www.newsbtc.com/news/ukgc-declares-bitcoin-as-cash-equivalent/To be more accurate, the requirements of the UKGC license when it comes to using crypto as a payment method are a bit too stringent to properly allow for crypto deposits, since they require the same levels of KYC, SoFi etc... which is a completely different business model for crypto-accepting bookies.So I should have said, doesn't easily allow. Now edited.Just to note that OP.

comments.author: Daltonik
comments.body: Yes, you are right there in the UKGC licensing there are also conditions for the use of cryptocurrencies, including KYC and measures to counter money laundering, the responsibility for this all lies with the casino accepting the cryptocurrency.
